issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

fields.description:
In JobHistoryEventHandler, flushTask is not purged after it's canceled so GC never sweep flushTask.
It can cause memory leak.
fields.summary: flushTimer in JobHistoryEventHandler should purge canceled flushTimerTask

This message was automatically generated.

Nice catch [~sarutak]. 

Looks good to me, I will commit it tomorrow if there are no further comments from others.

Could you elaborate more on the memory leak? The javadoc for the purge method states: {quote} *

Most programs will have no need to call this method. * It is designed for use by the rare application that cancels a large * number of tasks. Calling this method trades time for space: the * runtime of the method may be proportional to n + c log n, where n * is the number of tasks in the queue and c is the number of cancelled * tasks. {quote} I'm guessing the canceled timer tasks are reaped when they normally would execute and the timer notices they've been marked cancelled. Is this a case where we're queueing up tasks and canceling them faster than they normally execute?
